ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: A great class if you have any interest in Shakespeare.

YES please take it if you love theater and/or Shakespeare. You should be willing to put in the work though, because the class is usually very small and everyone is highly talented. If you work hard on it though, I think you'll have a great time!

This is a fantastic course that really teaches you a lot about acting and acting Shakespeare. Note that this is primarily intended for people who want to pursue acting and a lot of time notes are given about audition techniques. I found this particularly helpful but to the non-actor, it may not be. It is a lot of time both in and out of class, especially if you want to get a lot out of it, but it was definitely worth it.
If you are serious about acting (and prepared to work), it is an absolute must.
If you want to get better at Shakespeare you should definitely take this class.
Of course i recommend it. best class of my year.

This course is a life experience well worth having. If youre thinking of auditioning, put together an awesome monologue and go for it. I mean, its Shakespeare. And Murray Biggs is delightfully quirky and insightful. The work tends to be technical and detailedis this characters jacket is buttoned or unbuttoned? whats the most important word in this phrase?and its cool what a difference the details make. The atmosphere is at once laid-back and a bit stressful; Murray Biggs is kind and funny, but hell keep you on your toes, so be ready to really do your worktext, blocking, costumes, props. I made some room in my schedule for the class and was glad I did (though alas, this can only get you so far with group scenes). Take it.
